title: Blevins Gap Nature Preserve
text:
Blevins Gap Nature Preserve is a <a href="nature%20preserve">nature preserve</a> in southern <a href="Huntsville%2C%20Alabama">Huntsville, Alabama</a>. It measures in total and contains over 12 miles of trails within its borders. <a href="Cecil%20Ashburn%20Drive">Cecil Ashburn Drive</a> splits the preserve into two parts. The northern section measures with 4.5 miles of trails, a rocky <a href="Grade%20%28slope%29">incline</a>, and <a href="waterfall">waterfall</a>s. The southern portion measures the remaining and contains 8 miles of <a href="woodland">woodland</a> trails.
The trail system was designated as a <a href="National%20Recreation%20Trail">National Recreation Trail</a> in 2012.
History.
The preserve contains the southernmost remnant of the "Spacewalk Trail", which was constructed by <a href="Boy%20Scouts">Boy Scouts</a> in the 1960s and ran from <a href="Monte%20Sano%20State%20Park">Monte Sano State Park</a> to the southern edge of Green Mountain. The northern portion of the preserve, donated in 1988, was the first piece of land ever donated to a <a href="land%20trust">land trust</a> in Alabama. The Stevenson Trail and the Fanning Trail, both located within this northern portion, are named after the original donors.
Flora and fauna.
<a href="Armadillo">Armadillo</a>s, <a href="bobcat">bobcat</a>s, <a href="coyote">coyote</a>s, <a href="deer">deer</a>, <a href="fox">fox</a>es, <a href="opossum">opossum</a>s, <a href="raccoon">raccoon</a>s, and <a href="turkey%20%28bird%29">turkey</a>s live in the preserve. Plant species include the <a href="Neviusia%20alabamensis">Alabama snow-wreath</a>, the <a href="Cotinus%20obovatus">American smoketree</a>, and the <a href="Cypripedium%20parviflorum">yellow's lady slipper</a>, in addition to the endangered <a href="Clematis%20morefieldii">Morefield's leather flower</a> and <a href="Apios%20priceana">Price's potato-bean</a>.
